repo_notes.content: Textile is a transparent message transformation middleware for LLM applications. It wraps LiteLLM with zero API changes while providing powerful transformation pipelines. The project is organized into clear layers: /lite (public API), /core (internal implementation), /transformers (optimization), /embeddings (semantic operations), and /utils (helpers).
repo_notes.author: Blue Context Inc.

repo_notes.content: The /lite directory contains the public-facing API that maintains drop-in compatibility with LiteLLM. This is the primary entry point for users and should be prioritized in documentation.
repo_notes.author: Architecture

repo_notes.content: The /transformers directory contains the core value proposition - built-in transformers like DecayTransformer, SemanticPruningTransformer, SemanticDecayTransformer, and SemanticToolSelectionTransformer. These should be well-documented with examples.
repo_notes.author: Features

repo_notes.content: All code uses async-first architecture. Transformers are stateless and immutable. The design philosophy emphasizes zero API changes from LiteLLM while adding transparent optimization.
repo_notes.author: Design Philosophy

pages.title: Getting Started
pages.purpose: Overview of Textile, installation instructions, and quick start examples. Cover the basic usage pattern and demonstrate zero API change compatibility with LiteLLM.

pages.title: Public API (textile.lite)
pages.purpose: Document the public-facing API in textile/lite/: completion(), acompletion(), embedding(), and all utility functions. Explain how these maintain drop-in compatibility with litellm while adding transformation capabilities.

pages.title: Built-in Transformers
pages.purpose: Comprehensive documentation of all built-in transformers in textile/transformers/: DecayTransformer, SemanticPruningTransformer, SemanticDecayTransformer, SemanticToolSelectionTransformer, and TransformationPipeline. Include usage examples, parameters, and when to use each.

pages.title: DecayTransformer
pages.purpose: Detailed documentation of DecayTransformer: exponential decay for older messages, parameters (half_life_turns, threshold, min_recent_messages), and use cases for long conversations.

pages.title: SemanticPruningTransformer
pages.purpose: Document SemanticPruningTransformer: removes messages below similarity threshold, requires embedding model, and use cases for topic-focused conversations.

pages.title: SemanticDecayTransformer
pages.purpose: Document SemanticDecayTransformer: combines temporal and semantic decay, parameters (similarity_weight), and use cases for balanced context optimization.

pages.title: SemanticToolSelectionTransformer
pages.purpose: Document SemanticToolSelectionTransformer: filters large tool catalogs to most relevant tools, parameters (top_k, similarity_threshold), and use cases for function calling with many tools.

pages.title: Creating Custom Transformers
pages.purpose: Guide for creating custom transformers. Explain the ContextTransformer base class, transform() method signature, ContextWindow and TurnState objects, and best practices for immutable transformations.

pages.title: Core Architecture
pages.purpose: Document the internal architecture in textile/core/: ContextWindow, Message, TurnState, StreamingResponseHandler, and response patterns. Explain the immutable, async-first design philosophy.

pages.title: Embedding Models
pages.purpose: Document the embedding system in textile/embeddings/: EmbeddingModel protocol, LiteLLM-based implementation, and how embeddings power semantic transformers.

pages.title: Configuration
pages.purpose: Document the textile.configure() API, global configuration vs per-call transformers, embedding model setup, and environment variable configuration.

pages.title: Streaming Support
pages.purpose: Document streaming capabilities: how transformers work with streaming, StreamingResponseHandler, and response pattern transformations.

pages.title: Async/Await Support
pages.purpose: Document async-first architecture: acompletion(), aembedding(), and how the same transformers work in both sync and async contexts.

pages.title: Testing
pages.purpose: Overview of the test structure in tests/: unit tests, integration tests, and how to run the test suite. Include coverage requirements and test patterns.
